segment.tokens: He was a great though for all that
We could not help
loving him
mischievous as he was
He used to climb up often on my shoulder down into my pockets
if there was any thing good to eat thereabout
he would help himself without ceremony
when he felt particularly frolicksome
Sometimes he leaped from one person 's shoulder to another all around the room
The more we petted this little fellow
we gave him
the more good things the more roguish he became
At length he exhausted all my father patience by his mischief
One of his last tricks was
He gnawed a hole in a bag of meal
as he could
( this was oftener too )
for we fed him as often
as he needed to eat
eating as much this oftener too he carried away large quantities of the meal
he wasted it
He never worked harder in his life not even
when he was trying to get from the jaws of the old cat
than he did
when he was scattering this meal over the yard
Well we had a sort of a court about Billy after this
My father corn-house was the court
my father himself was the
We all agreed
that Billy was
though we differed to the punishment
the punishment ought to be inflicted
The question seemed to be to the language a _ grand larceny _
they use in courts of law
whether the theft was a _ petty larceny a _ grand larceny _
Alas for Billy and Billy 's friends
My father decided in his charge to the jury
that the crime must be ranked under the head of grand larceny
the jury brought in a verdict accordingly
My father pronounced the sentence
the sentence was
that the offending squirrel must die that same day
Billy seemed
what was going on
for he did not come near the house again till almost night
when he did come
one of my father 's men shot him
just as the sun was going down
he died
For a long time after that I cried
whenever I thought of poor Billy
Among the many juvenile friends with whom I have had more or less correspondence
Among the many juvenile friends with whom I have had more or less correspondence as the editor of a young people 's magazine is
resides at Saratoga Springs
I passed a few days at this watering-place last summer
called on Master William
for that is the of my friend
introduced to me a pet squirrel of his
I called Dick
Dick did not perform many very surprising feats
while I was
though I did not at the time set that circumstance down
as any evidence of a want of smartness on the part of the squirrel
for I well remembered
that it was a very common for pets sustaining even a much higher rank in the scale of intelligence to disappoint the expectations of those persons for the purpose of being exhibited
sustaining even a much higher rank in the scale of intelligence
the expectations of those persons think all the world of them
when they the pets are ushered into the presence of strangers
being exhibited
indeed I have some faint recollection of thus disappointing an over-fond nurse not unfrequently on similar occasions
There are some propositions waiting for proof
the truth it is quite as well to assent
when one hears them
the truth stated
among these propositions I class those
those relate to the unheard-of sagacity and genius of a darling pet
I make it a point to admit without demonstration or argument
that there never was another such a creature in all the world
Moreover I saw plainly enough in Dick 's keen , black eye , that he knew a thing or two
Dick keen black eye he knew a thing two
I could easily understand
how he might greatly endear himself to his little patron
Nor was I at all surprised
when I recently heard of the death of this favorite , that my young friend cried a great deal ; and I am sure I shared in some measure his grief
that my young friend cried a great deal
I am
I shared in some measure his grief
I immediately wrote to Willy to solicit a short biography of his favorite for my stories about animals
The request was kindly responded to Willy aunt " he resentful very capricious
by Willy 's aunt , from whom I received the following sketch
When Dick first became a member of the family
he was resentful very capricious
by degrees all these faults gave place to a sort of playful drollery , that called out many a laugh
playful drollery called out many a laugh
His cage was a fine large commodious place well lined with tiers
His cage furnished with every convenience
that he could have desired in a habitation
His cage not excepting a big wheel
a big wheel is general consent esteemed a great luxury for a squirrel
he often liked a change
when the door was left loose
he would soon find his way out

Then he had many hair-breadth escapes sometimes from dogs , who looked upon him as lawful prey sometimes from frolicsome and thoughtless boys , who forgot how much a squirrel suffers who is worried almost to death
dogs looked upon him as lawful prey
frolicsome thoughtless boys forgot
how much a squirrel suffers
who is worried almost to death
Sometimes he has been nearly abducted strangers
strangers saw with surprise so small an individual at large , and quite unconscious of the perils of a public street in a watering-place
when he was playing with his little master skipping from bough to bough on the large trees that sheltered his home running across
the large trees sheltered his home
he bounded from a branch to the roof of a three-storied house adjoining
On one of these occasions he skipping from bough to bough on the large trees that sheltered his home running across jumped from one of the angles to the court below
landed on all fours
stopped a second or two to decide not
if he were really not
then quietly trudged home to his cage
If he wanted a change
Dick had odd ways showing himself dissatisfied with his condition
when his house was too much exposed to the rays of the sun
In the summer he would give a queer little cry cage all
if no one heeded
a queer little cry he would lie
down flat all extended
he gasp
as if each moment was his
no coaxing could bring him to himself
until he was removed
then immediately he would jump up
he frisk about
he sit on his haunches
he laugh of his eye as merrily as if he had said , ' I know a thing or two -- do n't I though
out
if he had said
merrily as I know a thing two
do n't I
These manoeuvres were a clear
he could fall into one in a twinkling at any time
How many times he has led the children of the family , and the big children too through beds of beans , beets , and cucumbers through the tomato vines rose-bushes
when we were in full chase
that he had eluded us quite
was gone forever
he just ready to believe lo
there sat Dick in his wheel as demure as a judge looking as wise as possible at those very silly people , who would be running about so fast , on such a warm day
those very silly people would be running about so fast on such a warm day
He never liked any infringement upon his personal liberty
this he always resented
he would pretend to hide away clear into the pocket of any friend
he come
he peep at you clear into the pocket of any friend
jump up behind you
stand on the top of your head or shoulder
play all manner of pranks about your person
get
who was to have a supply of nuts
He would answer to his name
He follow
when called in the house of the house any where
He play all about the large house-dog , Tom
pat him on the ear
He gently pinch his tail
He poise himself on his back
He pretend to sleep by the side of him
if any one caught him
any one held him
as if he were imprisoned alas
what a struggle ensued
and then I grieve to say it
he would _ bite _ "
